item.title: Instant drop
item.dc:creator: @o.O_O.o o.O O.o
item.description:
@o.O_O.o wrote:

Yeah, I get that. It’s like that. Jagex made it so the killer sees them instantly, which is what you’re going for. When an NPC dies, you see their items instantly, and others don’t, so I’m saying read that.

Read full topic

item.title: Instant drop
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

I mean, the player that killed the other player has to wait to see the items, rather than instantly.

Read full topic

item.title: Instant drop
item.dc:creator: @o.O_O.o o.O O.o
item.description:
@o.O_O.o wrote:

Mine does that to… It’s definately something Jagex tweaked themselves; it’s set for everyone… Jagex set it so that only the original killer saw the items. Try looking at NPC drops when they die, since you see them automatically.

Read full topic

item.title: Instant drop
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

I am using a Devolution source, and I have a really annoying problem.

Player A kills Player B. Player B loses his items. Player A does not see the drop from Player B instantly. It takes about 30 seconds for it to appear.

Here is my youdied() method -

[code=java]public void youdied()
{

for(int rr=0; rr<playerItems.length; rr++) {
try {
if(playerItems[rr] > 0 && playerItems[rr] < 11999) {
ItemHandler.addItem(playerItems[rr]-1, absX, absY, playerItemsN[rr], KillerId, false);
deleteItem(playerItems[rr]-1, getItemSlot(playerItems[rr]-1), playerItemsN[rr]);

	}
} catch(Exception e) {  }

}
for(int r=0; r<playerEquipment.length; r++) {
try {
int item = playerEquipment[r];
if((item > 0) && (item < 11999)) {
remove(item, r);
}
} catch(Exception e) { sendMessage(“ERROR: Removing Equipment”); }
}

for(int rr=0; rr<playerItems.length; rr++) {
try {
if(playerItems[rr] > 0 && playerItems[rr] < 11999) {
ItemHandler.addItem(playerItems[rr]-1, absX, absY, playerItemsN[rr], KillerId, false);
deleteItem(playerItems[rr]-1, getItemSlot(playerItems[rr]-1), playerItemsN[rr]);
}
} catch(Exception e) { }
}
try {

	} catch(Exception e) {}
		ItemHandler.addItem(526, absX, absY, 1, KillerId, false);
	try {
	} catch(Exception e) {}
}[/code]

Any ideas? (Sorry for the crappy conventions.)

Read full topic
